facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1958 filed as appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1958. Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 3, 1956 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 25-D of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: judgment and order dated December 3, 1956, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 25-D of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated April 9, 1956,

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal No. 25-D of 1956 arising out of judgment dated April 9, 1956 in Civil Writ No. 8-D of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated April 9, 1956, of the said High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 8-D of 1955.

facts.text: Appellant joined permanent Government service on April 4, 1924.

anchor.surface_text: The short facts are these. The appellant stated that he joined permanent Government service on April 4, 1924. In 1947, before partition, he was employed as Assistant Secretary,

facts.text: In 1947 before partition, appellant employed as Assistant Secretary, Frontier Corps of Militia and Scouts in North-Western Frontier Province under External Affairs Department of Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: In 1947, before partition, he was employed as Assistant Secretary, Frontier Corps of Militia and Scouts in the then North-Western Frontier Province, under the administrative companytrol of the External Affairs Department of the Government of India.

facts.text: Post held by appellant in 1947 was a post in the Central Service, Class II.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant stated that the post which be held then was a post in the Central Service, Class 11. After partition, the appellant opted for service in India

facts.text: After partition, appellant opted for service in India and posted to Ministry of Commerce in October 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After partition, the appellant opted for service in India and was posted to an office under the Ministry of Commerce in the Government of India in October, 1947.

facts.text: In December 1949, appellant transferred to office of Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1949, he was transferred to the office of the Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi, to clear off certain arrears of work.

facts.text: In August 1951, appellant posted as Deputy Chief Controller of Imports, Calcutta, continued till September 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In August, 1951, he was posted as and Deputy Chief Controller of imports, Calcutta, and companytinued to work in that post till September, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant took four months leave on average pay, expiry on January 24, 1953, transferred as Section Officer in Development Wing of Ministry of Commerce.

anchor.surface_text: He then took four months leave on average pay and on the expiry of his leave on January 24, 1953, he was transferred as Section officer in the Development Wing of the Ministry of Commerce.

facts.text: Appellant thought transfer to Section Officer was reduction of rank and made representations.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thought that the order amounted to a reduction of his rank and lie made certain representations.

facts.text: Appellant applied for leave preparatory to retirement on February 6, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: As these representations bore numberfruit, he applied for leave preparatory to retirement on February 6, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant normally due to retire in April 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In that application the appellant stated Normally I am due to retire in April 1956 but I find it difficult to reconcile myself to the new companyditions of service

facts.text: Appellant prayed to retire from May 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Under the circumstances, I pray that I may be permitted to retire from the 1st May, 1953.

facts.text: On February 14, 1953, appellant amended leave application.

anchor.surface_text: On February 14, 1953, the appellant amended his leave application and said that he had been informed by the I -Administrative Branch

facts.text: On March 10, 1953, appellant informed he could not retire, granted leave from February 16, 1953 to April 30, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On March 10, 1953, the appellant was informed that he companyld number be allowed to retire at that stage, but the Ministry had agreed to grant him leave from February 16, 19 3, to April 30, 1953.

facts.text: On February 25, 1953, appellant wrote to Government contemplating joining Messrs. Albert David Co. Ltd., Calcutta, for two months training.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went on leave and on February 25, 1953, he wrote to Government to say that he was companytemplating to join the service of Messrs. Albert David Co. Ltd., Calcutta, and for that purpose he was accepting a companyrse of training in that Company for two months.

facts.text: In April 1953, appellant accepted service under Messrs. Albert David Co. Ltd., wrote to Government on April 6, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In April, 1953, the appellant accepted service under Messrs. Albert David Co. Ltd., and he wrote to Government to that effect on April 6, 1953.

facts.text: On June 16, 1953, appellant charged with violating r.15 of Government Servants Conduct Rules and Fundamental Rule 11.

anchor.surface_text: On June 16, 1953, the appellant was charged with hav- ing violated r. 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules and Fundamental Rule 11. Rule 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules states,

facts.text: Enquiry held by A.P. Mathur, report submitted on September 12, 1953, found appellant accepted private employment without sanction while in service.

anchor.surface_text: A. P. Mathur, Joint Chief Controller of Imports, was asked to hold an enquiry against the appellant on the charge mentioned above. ... The Enquiring Officer submitted his report on September 12, 1953,

facts.text: On April 14, 1954, show cause notice issued to appellant under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: On April 14, 1954, the appellant was asked to show cause in accordance with the provisions of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: On October 1, 1954, President passed order removing appellant from service with effect from that date.

anchor.surface_text: on October 1, 1954, the President passed an order in which it was stated that after taking into companysideration the report of the Enquiring Officer ... the appellant was accordingly removed from service with effect from that date.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the Punjab High Court by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in which his main companytentions were  a  that he had numberopportunity

facts.text: Dulat J. held against appellant, no contravention of Art. 311(2), and appellant contravened rules.

anchor.surface_text: Dulat, J., who dealt with the petition in the first instance, held against the appellant on both points. He found that there was numbercontravention of the provisions of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In the recent decision of Khem Chand v. Union of India  1  this Court explained the true scope and effect of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution. It was stated in that decision that the reasonable opportunity envisaged by Art. 311  2  of the Constitution included  a  an opportunity to the Government servant to deny his guilt and establish his innocence,  b  an opportunity to defend himself,

concepts.interpretation: Embodied in Art. 311(2) as three opportunities: deny guilt, defend, represent against proposed punishment.

issues.text: if the order of the President dated October 1, 1954, removing the appellant from service with effect from that date is invalid, as claimed by the appellant, by reason of a contravention of the provisions of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave and the only question for decision is if the order of the President dated October 1, 1954, removing the appellant from service with effect from that date is invalid, as claimed by the appellant, by reason of a companytravention of the provisions of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

issues.text: the alleged contravention of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: there was no contravention of the provisions of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution and on the second point, he held that on the facts admitted in the case there was no doubt that the appellant had accepted private employment in contravention of the rules governing the conditions of his service and there was little substance in the suggestion of the appellant that he had not sufficient opportunity to produce evidence. The second point no longer survives, and the only substantial point for our consideration is the alleged contravention of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, gave the appellant a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him

anchor.surface_text: It is no longer in dispute that the appellant did have opportunities  a  and  b  referred to above. The question before us is whether the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, gave the appellant a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him.

issues.text: whether the show cause notice complies with Art. 311(2) since it mentioned all three major punishments without specifying the exact one proposed

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee, who has appeared on behalf of the appellant, has submitted before us that the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, stated all the three punishments mentioned in Art. 311  2  and inasmuch as it did not particularise the actual or exact punishment proposed to be imposed on the appellant, the notice did not comply with the essential requirements of Art. 311  2  of the Constitution therefore, the final order of removal passed on October 1, 1954, was not a valid order.

Ltd. in the bona fide belief that Government had no objection to his accepting such private employment.

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice gave fuller opportunity; specifying alternatives does not invalidate; precedents distinguished

arguments.claim: Khem Chand requires the competent authority to tentatively propose 'one of the three punishments' specifically

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee has emphasised two observations made by this Court in Khem Chands case 1 . He points out that in connection with opportunity c aforesaid, this Court observed that a Government servant can only make his representation if the competent authority after the enquiry is over and after applying its mind to the gravity or otherwise of the charges proved against the Government servant tentatively proposes to inflict one of the three punishments and communicates the same to the Government servant.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, he has drawn our attention to the observations made in the judgment of the Judicial Committee in High Commissioner for India and High Commissioner for Pakistan v. I. M. Lall 1 , which observations were quoted with approval in Khem Chands case 2 . One of the observations made was In the opinion of their Lordships no action is proposed within the meaning of the sub-section their Lordships were dealing with sub-section 3 of s. 240 of the Government of India Act, 1935 until a definite conclusion has been come to on the charges, and the actual punishment to follow is provisionally determined on.

arguments.court_reasoning: Context was no second notice; 'actual' read in context

arguments.claim: Jatindra Nath Biswas, Dayanidhi Rath, and Lakshmi Narain Gupta require exact or particular punishment in second show cause notice

anchor.surface_text: We turn now to certain other decisions on which learned counsel for the appellant has relied. They are Jatindra Nath Biswas v. R. Gupta 1 , Dayanidhi Rath v. B. S. Mohanty 2 and Lakshmi Narain Gupta v. A. N. Puri 3 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: umberhing wrong in principle in the punishing authority tentatively forming the opinion that the charges proved merit any one of - the three major pen

arguments.court_reasoning: These cases did not hold that multiple punishments invalidate notice; proceeded on other grounds like no second notice or vagueness

arguments.claim: Mistakes of reference in President's order (r.13 instead of r.15, inapplicable para 5) make order invalid

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee referred to certain mistakes of reference in the order of the President dated October 1, 1954. Instead of referring to r. 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules, r. 13 was referred to. There was also a reference to para. 5 of a particular Government order which prohibited Government servants from taking up commercial employment within two years of retirement.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1954 Cal. 3.35- enquiry, but, before the punishment is imposed upon him, he must be told about the result of the enquiry and the exact punishment whi

arguments.court_reasoning: Inaccurate references not of vital importance; substance based on correct rules

arguments.claim: Real point in Khem Chand and I.M. Lall was absence of second show cause notice after enquiry, not specificity of punishment

anchor.surface_text: It is to be remembered, however, that both in I. M. Lalls case, 1 and Khem Chands case 1 the real point of the decision was that no second notice had been given to the Government servant concerned after the enquiry was over to show cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him.

arguments.claim: Specifying exact punishment in notice would require third notice if lesser accepted, against purpose of Art. 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: Let us examine a little more carefully what consequences will follow if Art. 311 2 requires in every case that the exact or actual punishment to be inflicted on the Government servant concerned must be mentioned in the show cause notice issued at the second stage. ... if the proposed punishment is dismissal, it is open to the Government servant concerned to say ... merits a lesser punishment ... If it is obligatory ... then a third notice will be necessary ... This will be against the very purpose for which the second show cause notice was issued.

arguments.claim: Mentioning all three major punishments gives fuller and better opportunity to show cause against any of them

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the show cause notice in the present case by mentioning the three punishments gave a better and fuller opportunity to the appellant to show cause why none of the three punishments should be inflicted on him. ... To specify more than one punishment in the alternative does not necessarily make the proposed action any the less definite on the contrary, it gives the Government servant better opportunity to show cause against each of those punishments being inflicted on him

arguments.claim: Show cause notice shows punishing authority applied mind provisionally to gravity of charges

anchor.surface_text: We desire to emphasise here that the case before us is not one in which the show cause notice is vague or of such a character as to lead to the inference that the punishing authority did not apply its mind to the question of punishment to be imposed on the Government servant. The show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, stated in clear terms that the President is provisionally of opinion that a major penalty, namely, dismissal, removal or reduction, should be enforced on you.

arguments.claim: Jatindra Nath Biswas proceeded on footing of no second notice, not requiring exact punishment

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Jatindra Nath Biswas 1 no second show cause notice was given and the decision proceeded on that footing. Sinha, J., observed ... before the punishment is imposed upon him, he must be told about the result of the enquiry and the exact punishment which is proposed to be inflicted. ... the decision proceeded on a different footing and was not rested on the ground that only one punishment must be mentioned in the second show cause notice.

arguments.claim: Dayanidhi Rath and Lakshmi Narain Gupta cases involved vagueness or non-application of mind, not invalidated merely by multiple punishments

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Dayanidhi Raths case 1 proceeded on the footing that if the punishment that is tentatively proposed against a civil servant is of a graver kind, he can be awarded punishment of a lesser kind but if ... graver ... prejudice ... In Lakshmi Narain Guptas case 2 the notice called upon the petitioner to show cause why disciplinary action, such as reduction in rank, withholding of increments, etc., ... did not indicate ... applied its mind ... We do not, therefore, take these decisions as laying down that whenever more than one punishment is mentioned ... the notice must be held to be bad.

arguments.claim: Show cause notice dated April 14, 1954 complied with Art. 311(2); removal order valid

anchor.surface_text: In the recent decision of Khem Chand v. Union of India 1 this Court explained the true scope and effect of Art. 311 2 of the Constitution. ... We have come to the conclusion that the three decisions on which learned counsel for the appellant has placed his reliance do not really support the extreme contention canvassed for by him, and we are further of the view that the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, in the present case did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 2 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Inaccurate references in removal order not vitally important

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the inaccurate references were of any vital importance. In effect and substance the order of removal dated October 1, 1954, was based on the ground that the appellant violated r. 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules and r. II of the Fundamental Rules he accepted private employment without sanction of Government while he was still in Government service.

holdings.text: the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, in the present case did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution. The appellant had a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him.

anchor.surface_text: We have come to the conclusion that the three decisions on which learned counsel for the appellant has placed his reliance do not really support the extreme contention canvassed for by him, and we are further of the view that the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Khem Chand, I.M. Lall, Jatindra Nath Biswas, Dayanidhi Rath, Lakshmi Narain Gupta as turning on absence of second notice, vagueness, or non-application of mind rather than multiple punishments listed; listing three major penalties provides fuller opportunity, shows provisional application of mind to gravity, aligns with Art. 311(2) purpose avoiding iterative notices.

holdings.text: Specifying more than one punishment in the alternative in the show cause notice does not make the proposed action indefinite; on the contrary, it gives the government servant a better opportunity to show cause against each.

anchor.surface_text: The show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, stated in clear terms that the President is provisionally of opinion that a major penalty, namely, dismissal, removal or reduction, should be enforced on you.

holdings.reasoning_summary: If only severest specified, lesser could still be imposed without grievance; listing alternatives enhances opportunity without prejudice; avoids third notice if representation leads to lesser penalty.

holdings.text: The three decisions relied upon by the appellant (Jatindra Nath Biswas, Dayanidhi Rath, Lakshmi Narain Gupta) do not lay down that a show cause notice mentioning more than one punishment is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We turn now to certain other decisions on which learned counsel for the appellant has relied. They are Jatindra Nath Biswas v. R. Gupta 1 , Dayanidhi Rath v. B. S. Mohanty 2 and Lakshmi Narain Gupta v. A. N. Puri 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Each case decided on distinct grounds: no second notice (Jatindra), juxtaposition creating vagueness (Dayanidhi), failure to apply mind to specific penalties from rule list (Lakshmi); not on mere multiplicity.

holdings.text: The inaccurate references in the President's order dated October 1, 1954 (r.13 instead of r.15, inapplicable para 5) are not of vital importance; the order is valid in effect and substance as based on violation of r.15 of Government Servants Conduct Rules and Fundamental Rule 11.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the inaccurate references were of any vital importance. In effect and substance the order of removal dated October 1, 1954, was based on the ground that the appellant violated r. 15 of the Government Servants Conduct Rules and r. II of the Fundamental Rules

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance prevails over clerical errors in rule citations; order explicitly considers enquiry report finding violation of correct rules prohibiting unsanctioned private employment while in service.

Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: we have come to the conclusion that the three decisions on which learned counsel for the appellant has placed his reliance do not really support the extreme contention canvassed for by him, and we are further of the view that the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, in the present case did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, stated in clear terms that the President is provisionally of opinion that a major penalty, namely, dismissal, removal or reduction, should be enforced on you.

we have come to the conclusion that the three decisions on which learned counsel for the appellant has placed his reliance do not really support the extreme contention canvassed for by him, and we are further of the view that the show cause notice dated April 14, 1954, in the present case did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

We turn now to certain other decisions on which learned counsel for the appellant has relied. They are Jatindra Nath Biswas v. R. Gupta 1 , Dayanidhi Rath v. B. S. Mohanty 2 and Lakshmi Narain Gupta v. A. N. Puri 3 .
